Name: Tripoley Word
Description:
A Fun Twist of the Classic game.
Players in this quick-playing word game compete to win the pot! Be the first to play a double letter word or seven-letter word and win the pot. Players compete for 12 pots total per round. No worries if play gets hectic, the letter tiles securely lock into the molded grid. And scoring is easy, the player with the most chips after three rounds wins!

For 2 - 4 players, ages 10 and up. Contents Include: 100 molded letter tiles, molded tile grid, perimeter chip board and instructions.

Name: Noddy Quoits
Description:
Players have to throw small rings, made of rubber, trying to land them on a board with hooks on it. You score points depending which hook it lands on (indeed, if it lands on one).
The board is illustrated with Noddy in the centre and Big Ears to the left and Policeman Plod to the right.

Name: Winnie the Pooh
Description:
Card game featuring characters from the Pooh stories by A. A. Milne.
A variation of the traditional playing card game called Beggar My Neighbour in Britain.
Players turn over a card from their stack. If it is a card without a number, the next player has a turn. If one of the numbered cards is drawn (they feature Christopher Robin, Kanga and Roo, Piglet and Winnie the Pooh) then the next player has to add cards to the central stack, how many cards being decided by the number on the previous card. If a player runs out of cards, he or her is out of the game. 'Last Man Standing' wins.

Name: The Jungle Book
Description:
A game released because of the Disney cartoon.
44 cards in four sets of eleven cards. Players have to form runs or sets (as in Rummy). The game ends when six hands have been played or at the end of any hand when a score of 100 or more is achieved.
The cards are illustrated with characters and scenes from the film.

Name: De Helden van onze Planeet
Description:
De Helden van onze Planeet is a card game in which players try to reach the number 2020 first, because 2020 is the year that WWF has set as goal to live in harmony with nature.

Players start in the year 0 and try to be the first to reach the year 2020 by playing out cards with numbers. These numbers represent years and players have to reach year 2020 exactly! There are of course special cards to block another player, steal years from another player, or play extra cards. The cards itself have photos and information on them about nature, wildlife, and preservation of the environment. So besides the game-play there is a learning factor for children.

Name: Rupert
Description:
A children's card game, rather like Memory, where you have to win pairs of cards. Complete luck at first but as more cards are revealed (and then placed back face-down), memory comes into the game. An easier version for very young children is also provided. The company also suggest that Snap could be played with the same cards.
44 cards, illustrated with characters from the Rupert comic strip and the Rupert Annuals that appeared every year.

Name: The Perishers
Description: Card game using characters from a popular cartoon strip in the Daily Mirror newspaper. Players have to play to tricks in the usual way but only Old Boot (the dog in the strip) cards are important because they will earn you points and that is a bad thing, because the player with the lowest total, wins.

Name: Combat, A Game of Skill
Description: Very cheap game, transferring a Battleships' type game to land rather than sea. Sold in packets of charts and rules, no box. Very rare to find. Probably from the Second World War period, when every boy wanted to be a General

Name: Five-A-Side
Description: A football board game from this mainly card game publisher. The board is made up of 13 squares the length of the pitch, and 7 squares wide. Players move their lead footballers around the pitch. Sadly, I don't have the rules, so I don't know how they are moved but it is probably by dice roll (given the age of the game). The box does say "The NEW Soccer Game of SKILL".

Name: Home Cricket
Description: The board is made up of 144 squares, each with either a number (the runs scored with that delivery) or a way of getting out. Each set of six squares is labelled with an over. You start in the first over and end with the 24th over. Players throw a die and move along the row labelled with the first over and check the result. Now the marker is moved back to the start of that over and a die is thrown again, and so on for six deliveries. Then it is the 2nd over, and so on. The publisher thought that it would be a good idea to say it was a game for more than the obvious two players. So three can play (two pair up against the other single player), or four (both teams consist of a pair of players) or five players (two teams of two players and the fifth player just acts as scorer and he gets to shout "Over" at the end of each six deliveries.

Name: World of Warcraft Trading Card Game: Assault on Icecrown Citadel Raid Deck
Description:
From the World of Warcraft TCG site:

Experience raiding content through the World of Warcraft Trading Card Game. Play the role of a hero as your storm Icecrown Citadel with your friends against the evil that has plagued Northrend for too long. Or, play as that evil and conquer the world!

This four-player game has everything you and three friends need to play all in the box. Play as Highlord Tirion Fordring, Lady Jaina Proudmoore, or Queen Sylvanas Windrunner and battle against the Lich King! Each player takes a deck, and the three heroes of Azeroth team-up to free the land from the threats of Icecrown Citadel. If the 3-on-1 seems unfair, know that the Lich King raid deck has some of the most powerful cards you've ever seen. He's no mere mortal! Plus, each deck comes with the hero's legendary weapon: the Ashbringer, Staff of Antonidas, Frostmourne, and Deathwhisper. The decks also feature new art for Fire Blast, Frostbolt, Counterspell, Multi-Shot, Redemption, Hammer of Justice, and others!

Cryptozoic has streamlined the raid deck experience, making it far more friendly to new players. There are no new rules to learn; each player takes his or her turn just as they would in a normal game of World of Warcraft TCG. The included rulebook ensures that even completely green recruits can jump in the action.

The three raiding decks easily convert into tournament-legal Core decks as well. Just replace the hero card, remove the legendary weapon, and you can battle at your local Core Constructed or Battlegrounds event.

Each four-player game comes packaged with an Assault on Icecrown Citadel Treasure Pack, and the Treasure Packs are sold separately as well. There are 20 uncommons, 7 rares, and 3 epics in the set. Each pack contains 9 foil cards (8 uncommons and 1 rare or 1 epic) unleashing never-seen-before allies, abilities, quests, and equipment cards into the World of Warcraft TCG card pool. Find Muradin Bronzebeard, High Overlord Saurfang, and Highlord Tirion Fordring as new allies to join your party. Recruit the best of Northrend before you go back to the mainland. You also have the chance to open Loot cards from Worldbreaker: Mottled Drake, Grim Campfire, and Landro's Lil XT.

Name: I Spy
Description:
A 1948 board game by the card game specialists, Pepys.
One player is the Spider and the other players are Flies. Inspired by Ludo, Flies have to get 'home' whilst the Spider must capture 5 Flies before any one Fly player gets all his Flies safely home.

Name: Miscellaneous Game Compilation
Description: A placeholder entry for compendiums/compilations/collections of games released in one package.  Typically these are traditional or children's games collected into one box.  The most common is a chess/checkers/backgammon/pachisi compilation, though other titles are also highly represented.
Families: Constructions: Châteaux of the Loire Valley (France)

Name: Crash Tower
Description: Players build the tower. The object of the game is to be the only player who doesn't make the tower tumble down.

Name: The Agency
Description:
Players are agents working for a counter terrorist organization.  They work with the other players to prevent disasters in the city.  They know where the terrorist targets are and must get themselves and other agents to those sites to diffuse the threat.  One player is a double agent working with the terrorists.  The other players must find a way to make the city safe in order to win.
Cards are played on buildings in the city where threats are taking place. On their turns the players choose one action from 9 available to diffuse the threats.  If all threats in the city are eliminated, the players win, but if there are three disasters, the double agent and the terrorists win.  A threat becomes a disaster if threat card is drawn that is identical to a threat already in place.  Players can deploy other players to danger zones, they can move themselves, follow a tip, gather intelligence, or interrogate suspects.  They can confront and kill other agents if they suspect them to be the double agent.

Name: March Madness 2011 Texel Pack
Description:
This scenario pack focuses  on the rebellion of the Georgian 822nd Battalion against the German Army on the island of Texel in Holland during the last days of the war.

Texel Island was part of the Atlantic wall, and the key battles of this rebellion involve fighting for control of these strongpoints.

Name: Wildebeest Chess
Description:
Wildebeest Chess is a large chess variant.

The chess variant attempts to bring balance between leapers and riders in the game.

The game is played on a board of ten rows and eleven columns. Each player has eleven pawns, two rooks, two knights, two bishops, two camels, one queen, one wildebeest, and one king.

A camel has an extended knight jump: it goes one square in one direction and three in the other. Camels may jump (like knights) over occupied squares.

A wildebeest has the combined moves of a camel and knight.

Name: 108th Kentucky Derby
Description:
A simulation of re-racing the 108th Kentucky Derby. Cards for all 32 horses that were eligible are included. Unusually, this seems to have been published before the real race was run, so the designer suggests that you could run the race more accurately after the horses are entered in real life.

Movement is by rolling dice and then looking at a chart on the back of each horse's card. On the back of the card, each horse has a set of target numbers for each quarter of the track. Dice are rolled and if you roll one of those numbers, the horse advances. If you don't, the horse doesn't move. Eight(8) horses are in each race, the players divide up the 8 horses.

As 32 horses are provided and only 8 run, you can play a series of 4 races, to use every horse once.

Name: Warhammer: Invasion – Fiery Dawn
Description:
Game description from the publisher:
 Fiery Dawn is the sixth and final Battle Pack in The Morrslieb Cycle for Warhammer: Invasion - The Card Game. When the small village of Swartzenholden falls to a violent raid by ungors, their attack culminates in an orgy of murder and destruction. But their excessive bloodlust catches the attention of the Chaos God Slaanesh, who has different plans altogether for the savage beastmen...

Fiery Dawn, a sixty-card expansion pack containing three copies each of twenty unique cards, brings a versatile selection of new units, tactics, and support cards to your Warhammer: Invasion deck. As the Dwarf's Spelleater Rune deflects hostile magic, the Empire's mighty Helstorm Rocket Battery scatters the ranks of opposing armies. Meanwhile, the Wood Elves unleash the power of the ancient Forest Dragon, and Slaanesh's Keeper of Secrets invades the minds of her weak-willed victims.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Warhammer Invasion – Living Card Game

Name: Run Around Fractions
Description:
6 games (3 outdoor games and 3 indoor games) that get kids off the couch and running while learning fractions.

Outdoor Games:
- Whole Lot: Learners race to join hands in order to become wholes.
- Order Order: Teams race to put fractions in order from lowest to highest.
- Line Up - Move-Up: Learners setp forward if a fractions is higher and step back if it is lower.

Indoor Games:
- Fraction Attack: Highest fraction card takes all.
- Trade Away: Trade cards with other poayers and become the first to make a whole..
- Fraction Solitaire: Beat the clock to make as many wholes as you can before time runs out.

Components:

     100 fraction cards (Including Half's, Thirds, Fourths, Sixths, and Eighths)
     15 Cips
     1 Timer

Name: Santa Claus: The Game
Description:
What child hasn't dreamed about being Santa Claus? Now they can with Santa Claus the Game! Open the Game box and immediately be transported into the Fantasy, excitement, and joy of Christmas.

In this delightful game players choose a sleigh and start at the North Pole. They race around Santa's Workshop trying to load their sleigh with 5 toys. Once a Santa has 5 toys, they fly off to the town to deliver the toys. Along the way, Santas encounter fun activities like belting out their best "HO HO HO" or Singing their favorite Christmas carol. The first Santa to deliver all their toys wins the game.

Name: Maximum Break
Description:
A Snooker-based game that needed to be 'made' by any interested gamer. It was self-published in a fanzine from the mid-eighties.

Cards provide a variety of options open to a Snooker player when he comes to the table. When a player takes on a pot, cards are used to generate three decisions. The first card drawn will tell if the shot is Easy, Medium or Hard. The next card will give you the first digit of a two-digit number between 01 and 99. And the third card completes the number. Numerous charts and tables are required for the game.

The rules allow for special events - a Foul Shot, a snooker, Bad Kicks, Getting out of a snooker and a choice of playing safely or riskily.

Name: Marketeer
Description:
"An exciting game of skill and chance with all the thrill of Stock Exchange speculation", from the box lid.

Players move round the track on the edge of the board (using the die) and they have a choice when they land on certain squares, to buy or sell stock. Chance cards here are called Ticker or Private Line cards. After an hour or so of play, the Markets close and players' stock are converted into cash. The winner is the player with the most money.

The game was produced in both a large box version and a small box version (but both had the same rules and components).

Name: Spellbound
Description:
A word game with 160 letter tiles, 4 racks and 4 playing boards. Each player uses a hand of 8 letters, replenishing them at the end of his turn. In your turn, you hope to make a word from your collection of letters, the longer the better. However, some thought is needed because once a word is played, it can be added to, to make a longer word. Thus you would score some points for the first word, and yet more for the longer second word. So it pays to be thinking this through. The score increases as words get longer (1 for a two letter word, 2 for three, 4 for four, 6 for five, 10 for six, and so on.
They obviously had AP in the 50's because the rules say "To save time, players should be considering their next play while their opponents are playing".
A more advanced game "For experts" allows you to intrduce a little more interaction.

Name: Pirates' Gold
Description:
"A Game of Adventure on the High Seas". The box is nice, shaped like a treasure chest, and the map comes rolled up with a ribbon round it.
The board is map of the sea between Sail Point Bay and Treasure Bay, superimposed with squares. The game uses dice but in a novel way. Turn order is decided by chance and that order of play continues for the whole game. We will call the first player 'the Leader'. He throws a red die and consults the compass at the top of the board. There are 6 compass points and each points in a different direction. The number rolled dictates the direction of movement, for all players, this round. Then the Leader throws a black die and moves his ship that many spaces in the correct direction. Each player after that does the same, throw the black die and move, but not the red die as that is only thrown at the start of the round. There is a little choice in movement. You can decide to 'tack' and move in the direct opposite direction of the compass throw, but you don't move so far, in fact, you might not move at all.
There are perils to be avoided, like rocks or the dreaded Seaweed Sea where you just float randomly until clear of it.
The first player to sail into Treasure Bay wins.

Name: Turnover
Description:
A word game that has elements of Reversi in that you turn over letters to your colour when you form a word.
2 player or a 4 player (partnership) game. Each player uses an identical set of 50 tiles, one marked with red, the other blue.
The first player lays down a letter, the second player lays a letter beside it (at the back or front). Play continues like this. If a player forms a word, all tiles in that word are turned over to his colour. Words are built up crossword fashion.
When all the letters have been used, the winner is the player with the most of his colour in the crossword.

Name: Stop or Go
Description:
A road safety game to educate children about the Highway Code, whether they are walking or cycling.
'Kerb Drill Bill' gives the advice.

This is the rarest Pepys game, by a mile. Even the guru of Pepys data doesn't have a copy. We know it existed because there were adverts for it in the back of the rules of most card games in the 40's.

Name: Mythic Migration
Description:
Mythic Migration is a 2 or 4 player, light strategy game. Players compete to be the first to get all their mythic creatures across the board.

The terrain is the obstacle. The board begins covered as plains (1 hex tile thickness) which no one can cross. During their turn players have two action points they can divide as they wish. They can move terrain hexes to build up (create mountains two tiles thick) for Yetis to cross, tear down (reveal the base board of water) for the Nessies to cross, or move their creatures towards safety (Yetis on mountains, and Nessies on water).

Beware, all your terrain movements potentially help your opponent(s), so minimizing the help you give them while maximizing their moves to your advantage is key!

Game Contents:
1 Full Color Rule Book
1 Wood Board (4 pieces)
4 Wooden Double-Sided Yeti Tokens
4 Wooden Double-Sided Nessie Tokens
28 Wooden Double-Sided Terrain Tiles

Name: Music Maestro Parade
Description: Music Maestro introduces your child to the sights and sounds of the orchestra. Play the audio cassette, Listen to the sounds of 32 Instruments in a narrated parade, Learn to match the sounds with the instrument names and pictures in a "Lotto" game.

Name: Land Grab
Description:
Land Grab is an abstract played with a standard chess set.  It was first published as part of Chief Herman's Next Big Thing.

The object is to, using your pieces, create a continuous line enclosing over half of the board, including your home row.  Pieces move as in normal chess, although the king is the only piece which can capture.  Pieces start off of the board and each turn a player can either place a piece on their home row or move one of their existing pieces.  Which pieces can be placed is determined by the number of pieces of both colors already in that column.
Families: Series: Chief Herman's Next Big Thing

Name: Gear Jacket
Description:
Gear Jacket is a print-and-play combat-based game for two to four players.  Each player takes on the role of a Gear Jacket pilot and battle his or her opponents in a variable arena.

In the not-too-distant future, a struggling television network gambled on the idea of a reality show about giant robots battling each other.  The concept was a huge hit.  Across the globe, young men and women dreamed of becoming Gear Jacket pilots and fighting for wealth and fame.

With Gear Jacket, you can take control of one of the famous Gear Jacket giant robots and take on one to three opponents!

There are twelve arena cards, each with six spots on which a player can land.  Any number of these arena cards can be combined in any configuration to create the combat arena in which players will battle.  Terrain tokens can be added to further diversify the arena.

There are twelve different Gear Jackets in the base game, with more planned for future expansions.  Players select the Gear Jacket of their choice.  Each player also takes five combat cards and a damage card.  Each combat card represents a different section of the Gear Jacket--Head, Chest, Arms, etc.  Combat is based on predicting the opponent's moves.  The attacker selects two combat cards, while the defender chooses three.  These cards are simultaneously revealed.  Any cards revealed by the attacker that are not matched by the defender count as hits.  Hits in different sections cause different amounts of damage, and may have extra penalties for the defender, as well.

There are also rules for game variants such as King of the Hill, Death Race 2000, and Tag that allow for further game diversity.

Name: Gelini Catch Me!
Description:
No sooner won, than ready to escape...

The cheeky Gelinis are not easy to get a hold of! You only barely manage to grab them before they are snatched away again. The winner is the player at the end of the game with the most Gelinis in his collection.

Contents...
45 Gelini cards
9 Gelini figures
Rule book.

In this game players attempt to catch as many of the nine Gelinis as they can. All the Gelinis (small plastic bears) start in the middle of the table. Each turn a player can play a coloured card to take to appropriate Gelini (bear)and put it in front of them. 
But watch out! Your opponents can steal your Gelinis from you. If he plays a card of the colour of Gelini you have he can take it from you, your only hope is to defend by playing yet another card of the same colour to stop him. Only good defense will help you win the game.

Name: Yomi: Cursed Cards
Description:
The cursed cards are a set of new, alternate character cards for Yomi. Yomi is a card game that simulates a fighting game. It tests your ability to predict how your opponents will act and your ability to judge the relative value of cards from one situation to the next.

You can use these cursed cards as a handicap to play against weaker or beginner players, or you can play cursed vs. cursed characters for a kind of hilarious lower-powered game.

The cursed characters all have a different epithet, too.

Grave, Wind Warrior -> Rusty Warrior.
Jaina, Phoenix Archer -> Phoenix Arsonist
Midori, Mentor Dragon -> Scrub Dragon
Setsuki, Ninja Student -> Outfoxed Ninja
Rook, Stone Golem -> Tiny Golem
DeGrey, Ghostly Diplomat -> Debaucherous Diplomat
Valerie, Manic Painter -> Depressed Painter
Geiger, Precise Watchmaker -> Careless Watchmaker
Lum, Gambling Panda -> Unlucky Panda
Argagarg, Water Shaman -> Savage Shaman

Name: Bloodline "The Family Tree"
Description:
The Kings Health is failing. You have a very small claim to the throne; if only your bloodline were just a little stronger! Always a bright child, you realize that history is written by the winner and it’s time to think like a winner. You’re going to rewrite a little history. The problem is that your opponents are trying to rewrite history as well. Can you create the strongest bloodline and become the ruler of the land?

Stratagy, Hand Management, Bluffing and a liberal dose of fun are all mixed into this game.
 140 cards
6 [You] cards in 6 colors
14 [wild] family tree cards (white)
120 family tree cards
    20 in each of 6 colors

Each set contains 
5 Great Grand Fathers (1 special)
5 Great Grand Mothers (1 special)
3 Grand Fathers (1 special)
3 Grand Mothers (1 special)
2 Fathers (1 special)
2 Mothers (1 special)
1 YOU card

Set up-
Take 1 set of cards for each player and the wild cards
Take the You cards for each of those sets and randomly distribute them to each player. This card is your color for this game. You will only score points for wild cards and your color played.
Shuffle all sets and the wild cards together and place them face down on the table where everyone can easily reach it.
Deal out 6 cards to each player
You are ready to begin.
On your Turn:
You may do only one of the following things on your turn.
   Play 1 card
   Draw 1 card
   Discard 3 cards and draw 2
   Swap an opponents played card with one from your hand
There is a hand limit of 7 cards. you may not have more that 7 cards in your hand at any time. (this included your YOU card.

You Start building your family Tree from your Great Grand Parents down to You. You must have played a Great Grand Father and a great Grand Mother next to each other (This creates a Mariage) in order to play a Grand Mother or Grand Father on that set. 
A complete family tree will consits of 4 married Great Grand Parents. The Second row will have 2 sets of Maried Grand Parents.  The third row of course will have Your Mother and Father. Last but certainly not least is you, in the fourth and final row.

The game ends when one player places their YOU card. At this point the round continues till everyone has the same number of plays, and points are tallied.
The person with the most points in their family tree is the winner of the game and becomes the ruler of the land.

Keeping your color secret from the other players as long as possible is a key factor in winning the game.  If plyers dont know what color you are they cannot steal a card from your family tree.

Name: Crazy Chicken
Description: Use your flippers to keep the eggs from getting into your 'basket'.  The winner is the one who has kept the most eggs from getting in.

Name: Quble
Description:
Quble – A Twisting, Turning, Fun Word Game!

It's a cross between Boggle and a Rubik's Cube.

To play Quble, players have the option to twist and turn the cube to build words in 60-second rounds using letters worth varying point values (point values are indicated on each letter).  The strategy is to search for the most or longest words and accumulate the highest score possible.  Each player must decide how to best allocate their play time between moving the cube or searching and calling out each word with its point value. Typically, a game consists of 2 to 5 rounds of play.  Players compete for the highest score by adding up the letter values for all words appearing anywhere around the cube.  The letters can wrap around the sides of the cube from one face to another and must links diagonally, vertically, or horizontally. In QUBLE JUMBLE and FIRST TO FORTY, scoring may be based upon the length of the word. The more letters in a word, the more points.

Besides word game play, QUBLE can also be played as a conventional brain teaser by matching up each face of the puzzle by solid colors.

Rulebook includes 7 variants, mostly in the scoring and win conditions.

Name: Scrabble Pocket Puzzle
Description: Two 4 x 7 sliding-tile games, with a letter and point value on each tile. The goal is to achieve a high score by forming interlocking words both horizontally and vertically.  Two boards allows for both solo and competitive play.

Name: Kings & Queens Rummy
Description:
Kings & Queens Rummy is a variant on contract rummy in which each round consists of two separate hands and players must play certain combinations of sets and runs with each hand while working toward the bigger goal of playing all of one's cards first.

To set up a round, the 216 cards – four decks, plus eight wild cards – are shuffled and each player dealt two separate piles of eleven cards. Players swap piles, then choose one of the two piles they hold to serve as their Queen hand. On a turn, a player draws the top card of the deck or the top three cards on the discard pile, optionally plays sets and runs and plays off opponents, then discards one card. To open, a player must first play a set and run from the Queen hand of 3-7 cards. Once the player does this, she may meld additional cards and play off opponents.

Once a player has run out of cards in the Queen hand, she picks up the other pile – the King hand – and needs to play a set of 3-7 cards from this hand before being able to play off opponents once again. The round ends when a player runs out of cards in her King hand. The other players are penalized based on the value of cards remaining in hand, and the player with the lowest score after five rounds wins.

Name: Ask Pickles
Description:
A double-box with two games. Happy Families was one but the other was a quiz card game, associated with Wilfred Pickles (1900-1978). Pickles was a noted radio performer for 30 years, starting in the 40's. He is pictured on the box.
The game has 29 cards. Each card has questions on them, and a score that can be earned if you answer correctly; 5 points (yellow), 10 points (red) or 20 points (blue).

Name: Popeye Knock Out
Description: 36 cards featuring Popeye characters regularly seen in the TV version which started in 1961. Popeye is pictured on the box. The game play is simple. Each player gets a stack of cards. These remain face-down in front of him. The first player turns over the top card of his stack. If it is a character card, play passes to the next player. But if it is a Spinach card, the next player must 'Put' the nimber of cards indicated on the can of spinach (either 1, 2 or 3). If no more spinach is added whilst he is taking this action, all the cards played go to the player who played the spinach card and he puts them face-down under his stack.

Name: Huckleberry Hound 'Booby'
Description:
This is a slightly altered variant of Old Maid or Donkey. 36 cards featuring characters from The Huckleberry Hound Show, such as the Hound himself, Mr. Jinks, Yogi Bear and Pixie & Dixie.
Players must collect pairs of the same card. Curiously, the company have included two 'Booby' cards and added the instruction 'one is spare and should be removed before dealing'.

Name: Tilt Score
Description:
Object of the game is to manipulate Your marbles into the scoring wheel and be the first player whose scoring wheel makes one complete revolution.

Each player places his marbles into the outside channel of his teeter board. A player's scoring wheel is the same color as his teeter board. 
At the word "GO" players work their teeter board in a teeter-totter motion manipulating their marbles up & down the teeter board and through the opening, attempting to manuever them into the scoring wheel. The first player whose scoring wheel makes one complete revolution wins the game.

Name: Mini-Motocross Game
Description:
"A relatively abstract game but still intensely exciting form of Motocross." - from the rules.
Players roll dice to create their rider by comparing each roll to the Preparation Chart. 5 rolls are needed per rider, giving him Basic Speed, Skill Rating, Block Ability, Control Rating and Stamina Factor. These five abilities are tested at different times during the race. It is a race game but has no board, laps are recorded on paper. The winner is the first rider to complete a set number of laps.
First published in Games Unlimited's Random fanzine.

Name: Ein, Zwei, Drei
Description:
A partnership card game, played with traditional playing cards.
Each player is dealt 13 cards but only 12 tricks are played for. The 13th card is used at the start to give to your partner. This should indicate how many tricks you think you can win. The card will be used later in the game. Tricks are won by playing 1, 2 or 3 cards. 1 card played is just a normal trick as in Bridge or Whist, but there are specific rules about what constitutes a trick playing 2 or 3 cards.
100 points equals a game. Before play begins, players decide on a 'best of' five, say, i.e. the first pair to score three games would be the winner.

Name: Back to Iraq (Third Edition)
Description:
Back To Iraq, 3rd Edition (B2I3e) is a "what if" simulation of the fighting that might occur across the northern littoral of the Persian Gulf if the US-led anti-terrorism Coalition decides on a ground war to finally settle with the Baghdad regime.

B2I3e is a two player wargame of low to intermediate complexity that posits this might-be war lasting about a month. We believe that is about the maximum time before the Coalition Ground force's diminishing supplies, coupled with a loss of the domestic political will necessary to continue the fighting, would bring about a settlement if victory were not achieved in the field.

(Form the introduction).

Major changes with the previous editions are the units, with new Order of Battle and factors. The units also are now mostly "two steppers". The combat table is also different at all, with separate combat tables for coalition and Militant Islamic.

Two scenarios, one against Iraq and Al Qaeda, and the second also against Iran and Iraq. Turkish and Syrian intervention is possible in both scenarios.

The Advanced rules cover Strategic targets, Airstrikes, Special Operations Forces, Command and Control and Additional Forces

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 17 miles / 27.54 km
Unit: Brigade to Army

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (176 5/8" counters)
One 24 page rules booklet
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Cyclades: Hades
Description: Cyclades: Hades, an expansion for Cathala and Maublanc's Cyclades, consists of four modules that can be used individually or combined in various ways. In the Cyclades base game, players fight for domination over archipelagos in ancient Greece. They make offerings to gods to secure their favors and summon mythological creatures. The Hades expansion allows players to add Hades (no surprise there) to other gods present in the base game: Zeus, Ares, Athena, Poseidon and Apollo. Players will be able to build a Necropolis and summon undead armies when they gain favors of Hades.

Name: Reaching for the top
Description:
In this game the players build a pyramid of glass marbles. Aim is to place the last marble on top of the pyramid.
Besides placing a new marble of his color on the board, a player can move one of his marbles already on the board by raising it one or two levels. Or a player can take back two marbles from the board by making a square using four of his own marbles.

This way a dynamic game is going on with a rising and shrinking pyramid.

Name: Il Gioco del Cinema
Description:
Italian game. The scope of the game is that one of guess the titles them of two films and to prepare a cinematographic troupe composed of 8 members.

The mechanism of the game is question and answer: if the answer is exact the player advances the number of spaces indicated on the cad, and will play out the event on the back of the card; if incorrect, the player moves back two spaces and is affected by the text on the space.

2340 questions in 12 categories.

Name: Silly Socks
Description:
Collect pairs of socks, but don't pick up the underpants!

Each player gets three silly socks to start. On your turn take an item from the washing machine. If it's a sock that matches one of your three, put the pair in your laundry basket. But be careful. If you pull out a pair of pants you'll lose one turn until you can try for silly socks again. The first player to collect three matching pairs wins. For 2 to 4 players, ages 3 to 5.

Name: Pinpoint the Bomber
Description:
This is a book game. Published as a book it includes multiple black & white and color maps. There are 3 games described, the Red, the Green and the Black game.

The Black game is a solo effort to see how long it takes and how accurate you can be with determining your map pinpoints.

The Red game is meant for 4 players or fewer.  It is a game of chance and is won by the first person to reach the bombing target (the German city of Coblenz).

The Green game is for any number of players, again as a game of chance but requires finding Pinpoints via Latitude and Longitude.

In the Red and Green games a number of aircraft set off from their base in Kent to bomb a target at Coblenz.

The games requires the player to copy and create miniature airplanes, Compass Rose, 10 deg angle indicator and Latitude/Longitude Finder.

The game includes maps as well as extensive briefing triggered by either a draw from a deck of cards or dice roll.  The players continue to roll/draw cards until they land on the target by exact count. Any overshooting requires the bomber to fly back around.

A briefing can have extensive instructions causing the player to head off track or be attacked by enemy fighters ending in a change of course and position on the map.

Name: Sky Castles
Description:
Sky Castles is a tile and worker placement game where the players collect gemstones from castles in the clouds.  The theme is aimed at children, but the game claims to provide scope for strategic play at all levels.

The tiles depict a cloudscape dotted with gemstones.  Each turn the player selects one of four face-up tiles and places it into the cloudscape so that the borders match adjacent tiles, and can optionally place a sprite token to claim a cloud or section of sky.  There are three scoring rounds where the players score points for the gemstones that their sprites have claimed.

The gameplay is similar to other tile placement games (e.g. Carcassonne) but Sky Castles has less complexity and claims to be suitable for a younger audience while retaining similar strategic options.

Name: La guerra de los signos
Description:
In this game, two spacecraft armies fight each other as they try to reach the earth first and conquer it.

Each army is composed by 6 combat modules, each one representing one of the signs of the zodiac, and a mothership. The motherships are able to shoot "disc missiles" but only only can move laterally along the gameboard's central circle, while the combat modules can move forward and feature an spring-based system that makes them "explode" in case one disc missile hits it's front.

At the start of the game, each combat module is placed over it's correspondent sign in the circle, and the motherships are placed in each side of the gameboard. The starting player moves one of his modules one square forward and then shoots his mothership. If he hits and destroys one of the other player's modules, he can advance one of his again, until he fails, ending his turn. The first to move one of his modules over the central square (The earth) wins the game.

Name: Tic Tac Throw
Description:
Aim! Throw! Claim a square! Or knock your opponent out of there!

The classic 2-player skill game Tic Tac Toe just got more action-packed with Tic Tac Throw! Players must throw the cubes with "x" and "o" on the vinyl board in right places to form the row.
Try to be the first to get Tic Tac Toe!

Name: Captain's Log #1
Description:
From the back:
CAPTAIN'S LOG #1 features the short story and scenario, "Objective: Juggernaut," by Christopher Allen. This story creates a unique background for a five player situation which requires skill in combat and finesse in diplomacy. Involved are the Federation, Tholian, Klingon, Orion and the fearsome extra-galactic Juggernaut.
Also included in CAPTAIN'S LOG #1 are the diagrams and rules needed to resolve combat in the same hex. This system will make combat in the same hex more realistic and systematic.
NOTE! This product adds new play situations and rules for the STAR FLEET UNIVERSE. YOU MUST HAVE the boxed edition of STAR FLEET BATTLES to play any of the scenarios presented. Additionally, many of the scenarios draw on material published in the three STAR FLEET BATTLES EXPANSIONS. These products are recommended for maximum enjoyment of the material presented.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Starmada: Fleet Ops
Description:
Starmada: Fleet Ops is a "fleet-scale" game using the same database as Starmada: Admiralty Edition science-fiction starship combat game. S:FO is very similar to S:AE in many respects, but Starmada: Fleet Ops' flow is intended to be faster-moving and more abstracted.

Game scale is "grand tactical", each ship is a single counter on the map, and its statistics (damage level, weapons, and so on) are tracked individually, although not in as much detail as Starmada: Admiralty Edition. (Any ship you can build using Admiralty Edition's ship design rules can be represented in Starmada: Fleet Ops, making the two games highly compatible).Construction rules are included, and also guidelines on converting Admiralty Edition ships to Fleet Ops statistics. An entire fleet of ships can be represented on a single standard sheet of paper.

Play is simultaneous. Each player takes turns giving orders to his units by placing a marker on top of one ship to indicate the orders it has been given. Once all ships have orders, initiative is determined. The player losing initiative moves all his ships first (giving the non-moving player an advantage), but then fires first in the subsequent fire phase (gaining an advantage).

Movement and firing are both simplified and sped up from Admiralty Edition, reducing the amount of record keeping and the number of die rolls. Mechanics new to the Starmada system are introduced, including morale and command ships.

The product is available as either a download in Adobe .pdf format, or as a print-on-demand saddle-stitched book (44 pages). Additional material, including printable colour counters and map sheets, is available for free download from Majestic 12 Games' website for purchasers of either format.

Name: Socker
Description:
Socker is a two player breakthrough abstract board game that simulates a soccer or rugby-like game where socking opposing pieces is a means to the end zone.

Socker is played on a 9x11 field, 9 columns and 11 rows. Each player has five man tokens (for example meeples), called sockers, and there is a ball token.

To set up the game, the ball is placed in the center space of the board. Players toss a coin to see who plays first. Starting with the toss winner, each player places all his or her sockers upright on any empty spaces that are in their nearest half of the field, but not adjacent (vertically, horizontally or diagonally) to the ball and not in the center row.

Players continue alternating turns and do the following.

On a turn, a player must perform one to three actions listed below using any of his or her upright (referred to as active) sockers.

     Move.  An active socker may be moved to any adjacent empty space. This includes the goal and out of bounds areas. However, at the end of a player’s turn, no more that three of his or her sockers may be in the goal and out of bounds regions.
 Kick. If an active socker is adjacent to the ball, the ball may be kicked directly away one space provided the destination space is empty.

Sock. If an active socker is adjacent to an opponent’s socker, then the opponent’s socker may be pushed directly away one space provided the destination space is empty. The pushed socker is then put on its side to indicate that it is inactive and will not be able to perform any actions for one turn.

Any action or active socker may be used multiple times. Player may use any combination of actions and active sockers, and in any order they like.

When a player completes his or her actions all that player’s inactive sockers are put upright and become active again. This ends the player’s turn.

The goal of the game is to kick the ball over your goal line, into your farthest 1x9 row.  Players can choose either of the following winning conditions: first to score a set number of goals (usually one), or most goals after a set number of turns followed by sudden death if necessary. After a goal, players should use the setup procedures with the non-scoring player going first. For sudden death, only two sockers per player are used, and a coin toss is used to determine who plays first.

Special Rules

Out of Bounds: The first and last columns of the playing field excluding the goal spaces are out of bounds. If the ball is pushed out of bounds, the ball is immediately moved to the center space of the same row. If the center space is occupied, the owner of the occupying socker can choose any empty space adjacent to the center space.

Repeat Positions: When a position is repeated, the player that plays next gets one extra action (total of four instead of three) to break the deadlock.

Static Positions: The maximum number of sockers on the edge is three. This prevents unmovable defensive positions behind the goal line or along the sides of the board. That is, positions where the offensive player can not push the ball or an opponent's socker.

Name: Tenis: Diana
Description: This is a very simple, turn-based, game, aimed mainly at kids. The objetive is to score the more points possible, using little rackets to throw some badminton-like plastic cones into a score field. The one who get the most points, wins.

Name: Time Bastards
Description:
A devilish print-and-play game of temporal competition, where two time travellers compete to complete four objectives by travelling back in time to alter four separate time-lines, and interfere with each other's plans.

To play the game, you will need :
- 1 A4 printout of the board (see files or images section)
- 4 red counters
- 4 blue counters
- 10 black counters
- 1 D6

Rules are printed on the board, and transcribed here :

Place player pieces on the beginning of any timeline (I - IV, coloured), and a marker on the beginning of the clock track (X).

At the beginning of each round, advance the clock marker one hour.
If the end of the clock track is reached by the first clock marker, add a second at X, and continue advancing this, so that 24 hours are played.
When the second clock marker reaches the end of its track, the game ends.

The player with the greatest number of achievements (A or B) wins.
If more than one player is tied for the greatest number of achievements, the player with the least pieces wins.
If more than one player shares the lowest number of pieces, the player whose oldest piece has advanced the farthest through time wins.

In turn, move your earliest piece (that nearest to X along the time-lines I - IV) forward one space, or roll 1D6.
    On a roll of 6, you may move any piece on the board (with the exception of achievements) one space in any direction along its time-line.
    On any other roll, place a new piece on any time-line, that number of spaces back in time from your earliest piece, counting from the previous space.
        If the new piece is placed beyond the starting space, it is lost in time, and your turn ends.

If you land level with another of your pieces, remove the older of the two pieces, and collect the achievement associated with its time-line if you have not already.
If you land on the same space as another piece, move that piece to the equivalent time on any other time-line.

For a co-op game, use only one clock counter (12 hours), and ignore one of the scoring tracks.

Name: Nick Dubronski jagt Sinto Manao
Description: "Nick Dubronski jagt Sinto Manao" is a cooperative adventure game themed around the german amateur audio drama series "Nick Dubronski". Players choose there character from 18 special agents. The agents have to fight together against the super-demon Sinto Manao. Sinto Manao tries to gain his force by controlling other dimensions and recruit an army of terror. During the course of the game, players will upgrade their agents by acquiring skills, allies, items, and weapons. It's up to the players to clean out the world by fighting many different types of henchman, but their main goal is to close portals to other dimensions that are opening up around the world. At the end there is a final battle against Sinto Manao. Are the agents well-prepared?

Name: Crib Football
Description:
You must know the rules of Cribbage to play this game, but the scoring system means that quite different tactics are required.
Each player tries to score goals and for a shot on goal, you need to score dozens (or more) with your hand. Opponent will get a chance to save the shot.
Further rules cover the actual player 'on the pitch' who scored the goal. The time in the match when the goal was scored. Penalties, and Home Advantage.

Published by Games Unlimited Ltd. in their house fanzine Random.

Name: Kunitori! Is the World on Fire?
Description:
In Kunitori! Tenka: Is the World on Fire?, the players are feudal lords in medieval Japan, once again fighting for unification of the lands. In this deck-building game, you must use your tacticians, allies and money effectively to buy cards such as Cavalry, Fortresses and Gold, gradually building your deck of cards.

As the game nears its end, players can take command of their generals and troops to go to battle against the other players, trying to gain as many lands as possible. This battle heavily influences the game. All after fights of the samurai end and players tally their victory points, will you be the strongest feudal lord?

Integrates with:

    Kuni Tori!

Name: Newmarket
Description:
A card game that is similar to the traditional playing card game of Racing Demon. One player is the Bookmaker and offers odds on each of the horses in any one race.
For the race, cards are turned over and the horse named advances along the 'course'. And there are wild cards that affect the race; Jockey Falls, Little Brown Dog, Whip, and Spur.
There is no skill at all apart from betting wisely or, if you are the Bookmaker, offering the right odds so that you can make a profit

Name: Gold Stock
Description:
This game is composed of eighteen wooden chips (pawns) in two colors (nine for each player) and a board with seventy-seven cells, of which eighteen are marked with two different colors.

Each player place his pawns in their respective colour cells and the game begins. Players move their pawns alternately one by one. The movement is one square forward or sideways, but never diagonally or backward. It’s forbidden not move a pawn in the player's turn.

When a player, after moving a pawn, trap a chip of the other player between two of his own, that chip is removed. Only one chip can be removed in each turn.

The game ends when no piece can be moved forward, being all in the last cell. The player who gets the most pawns to the last row of the board, opposite to the area in which he started, wins the game.

This game is part of the rare "Club series" from NAC, a company more known for his wargames than for this kind of abstract games. The other known titles from this series are: The Backbone, Manhattan and Daiquiri

Name: Radar 2000
Description:
This title covers two different games:
- a classical battleship-like game, which, by using tracking system by means of polar co-ordinates, is more modern than former types;
- a "battle of missiles", new game in which success depends mainly on deduction and method.

Both games require different printed forms, but are provided with the same support for two Radar screens: the first one is used to "emit" missiles and to track firing against the enemy, the second one to place ships or missiles and to "receive" enemy firing.

Name: Tifon 4
Description:
4 spinning tops for 4 different games, that's essentially Tifon (Typhoon) 4.

Although other elements like marbles or a shooting platform are included, the metal spinnings tops, identified as "spaceships" in the gamer's manual, are the main element in the different games described:

-Cosmic Soccer: The marbles are placed in the center of the field and, then, a special spinning top is released on it, throwing the marbles into the different scored goals on each side of the field. The player with the most points, wins.

-Starship stop: A spinning top it's thrown into a flat surface and the players try to "catch" it with the shooting platform and its magnetic projectile. 10 points are given to the one who catch the top and 5 to the one who just knock it down.

-Competition: The players spin their tops and the one with the top that falls last, wins.

-Fight: The four tops are thrown into the field and crash against each other. The player with the last top standing, wins.

The manual encourages the players to create it's own games and variations, and suggest some possibilities.

Name: Imperial General
Description:
In Imperial General, the armies are equal, the odds are equal, the strengths are equal, the difference is you!
   In Imperial General both sides have identical decks and start in identical setups.  Then, each turn, the players select what their next formation change, or order, will be for the next turn.  The changes are compared and a matrix on the bottom of each card shows how may points your opponent loses.
   Rounds continue until one side has lost an entire company.  THen the game ends and the side with the most points (men) remaining-wins.
   Imperial General is part of the Warcoach Games "10 Minute War Game" series.

Name: Senator Please
Description: Players move around the board to complete with all "Senators" and 48 state questions (which is the amount of states in the USA at the time). They have to collect enough cards and answer "special" question to become President and win the game.

Name: Autobackgammon
Description:
When backgammon became a fad in the early seventies, the game went from that thing on the back of inexpensive checker boards to the gambling rage of the jet set.

This solitaire game was created to cash in on the craze. Sixty pre-programmed games have been divided into four courses of fifteen games. Place one of the games into the tray. Using the slides in the frame of the tray, the player only sees one move at a time. After sizing up any given situation, the player advances a slide to see what backgammon champion Tim Holland would have done.

The game contains the tray, a really cheap backgammon set, thirty two game cards and rules.

Name: Spello
Description:
The gameboard is a nineteen-by-nineteen grid with the corners missing; the first and last rows and columns are elongated. In this elongated spaces, players may place more than one letter to make their words.

From a pool of letters, the players determine which letters will be randomly added to their hands. The players, in turn, add their letters to the grid to make words in crossword fashion.

The game contains one sheet or rules and nineteen games printed in ten sheets of paper. The game is consistent with Robert Mansfield’s packaging that allows a complete set to be stuffed into a standard business envelope.

Name: The KINGPIN! Game
Description:
The PRIMARY OBJECTIVE: 
"Finish them! Before they finish you!"

Gain the reign of the nefarious organized underground.

Rollers (players) will gamble and make deals, purchase and flip (sell) from the various high-end illicit contraband markets (on domestic soil/US & foreign lands).

This is a roll-and-move game. Rollers roll the dice and move their game piece throughout The KINGPIN! Game world's cities, states and countries. As rollers travel The KINGPIN! Game world they are allowed to buy or sell available products, pick a PUSH YOUR LUCK card (like "chance" or "community chest") which gives rollers a 50/50 chance of getting or losing monies. Rollers can also gamble in "La$ Vega$", "3Card MONT3 CARLO", or "AC", for their chance at the 7 / 11 jackpot roll. Rollers must increase their wealth and their worth while eliminating all street competition.

Rollers can hire one of The KINGPIN! Game's paid "KILLA$" to attempt to assassinate other rollers in The KINGPIN! Game, done by paying for hire - The KINGPIN! "KILLA$" (hit-men/assassins). The KINGPIN! "KILLA$" are hired killers in The KINGPIN! Game that operate for various fees/costs {$75,000 - $1M}.

The goal of The KINGPIN! Game is to be the last one standing! The solo survivor ~ the realized vision of the primary objective...

The KINGPIN!

The KINGPIN! Game comes with: 
The Official The KINGPIN! game rule book and soundtrack 
(hard copy of the rule book and CD with rules set to KINGPIN! MU$IK as well as a The KINGPIN! Game related score/sound Track) on one CD

Name: Go For Broke: America's Immigrant Heroes – A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book
Description:
In February 1942, President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued the first of a series of executive orders that would send over 100,000 American citizens to concentration camps. One year later, a Japanese-American regiment began to form. The 442nd Regimental Combat Team, eventually also including the 100th Infantry Battalion formed in Hawai'i, racked up more decorations than any regiment in American military history: 18,143 awards for battlefield valor, including 21 Medals of Honor.

Go for Broke is a book supplement for the Panzer Grenadier series, with 20 new scenarios by Mike Perryman depicting the actions of America's toughest fighters in the last years of the Second World War. There are also 77 new die-cut and mounted playing pieces depicting this regiment in its own color scheme.

Go for Broke is not a complete product: ownership of 1940: The Fall of France, Elsenborn Ridge and Battle of the Bulge is required to enjoy all of the scenarios.

Name: EIC League
Description:
EIC League is a tactical combat / RPG crossover that is completely customizable. You add your own dice and playing field to the EIC League rules that you download, and you are ready to go.

Every player is assigned the same number of credits (a budget) that they have to spend to buy and customize their units.

Players design units (either bipeds or tanks), equip them with the 7 ratings they need (body material, attack, defense, power, speed, detection & ECM), then outfit them with weapons, shielding, and special movements. After the units are completed, they pit their team against one or more opponents. The game is like chess on steroids!

The infinite combinations of weapons, movements and defenses against the other team's weapons movements and defenses makes for a unique playing experience each and every game.

Unit design can take up to 2 hours for first time players, and play time can range anywhere from 30 minutes to 4 hours. The object of the game is to obliterate the opposition and collect credits for rewards. With those credits, you can buy more units or upgrade your existing units through the roof.

Strategy is the key to winning. Do you use a bunch of fast and light units or just work with a couple of super strong slow units, or go with a mix of everything? Depending on what you do and what each opponent does, you can battle for hours or you can make a fatal mistake and have things end very quickly. No two games are alike!

Name: Legend of the Galactic Heroes: My Conquest Is a Sea of Stars
Description:
Based off of the cult classic series of science fiction novels, Legend of the Galactic heroes tells the story of two empires in space, fighting a war for total control. On one side, the Free Planets Alliance, a corrupt democracy lead by a charismatic fraud, and on the other side, The Empire, a Benevolent Monarchy, lead by the Imperial Kaiser.

Legend of the Galactic Heroes: My Conquest is a Sea of Stars. puts you in command of one of these nations, on the eve of war, will you come out victorious, or will the underhanded dealings of your neighbor with the neutral world of Phezzan put you at a loss.

Game play is based around two boards, one is the strategic board where you command all the resources of your nation, and the other is the tactical board, where you can fight out the battles between massive fleets, numbering in the thousands.

Complexity - Moderate, only slightly more complex then a game of Axis and Allies.

Length - In Excess of Ten hours for a full game, individual battles take up to thirty minutes or so.

Suitability for Solitaire Play - Moderate, some elements of the game revolve around hidden units, but the rules for that are easily removed.
Families: Setting: Legend of the Galactic Heroes

Name: Nationale 7: Lapalisse
Description:
You are driving through the city of Lapalisse and try to collect two items and find one truth. When you get your items and truth, you rush out from the city. First one who leaves wins the game.
You move your car by pushing new tiles to the Nationale 7. When your car is in the right place you park and collect an item or leave Nationale 7 and turn to side roads in Lapalisse. You collect or lose the truth by driving to a "truth" tile.

Name: Abel-Klingers "Grosse Fahrschule"
Description:
Goal: Be the first, who visits all 12 lettered points (A-M) avoiding major mistakes

1  Preparing the map first you have to cut trees, buildings, a bridge and glue/insert these into the
    board, place policemen... 
2  Follow the streets/roads in recommended directions by rolling the die
3  Stop at lettered places (and policemen)
4  Explain the traffic signs you pass by; various mistakes will lead to penalties

Name: Unsere Lufthansa
Description:
Goal: Be the first to travel with 'Lufthansa GDR' from Berlin via Praha to Budapest

1. Choose your coloured plastic plane and roll the die by turns - you may start with a '6' at once, otherwise follow a circuit - Kicking your teammate(s) is not allowed
2. Follow instructions if you land on a marked area
3. Stopover in Praha
4. Step out in Budapest and win  - that's it

Name: Geus en Spanjool
Description:
This game is situated in the low countries during the revolt against Spain, resulting in the independency of the Dutch Republic.
One player takes the Spanish side and the other the Dutch. Control of the land is achieved by controlling the various cities. To signify the control each city is covered with a chit which has a Spanish side and a Dutch side. 
At the beginning of the game the players decide on the number of rounds they will play (about 10 rounds per hour can be played, 20 to 30 round are recommended) and a die is rolled for each city. On a roll of 1, 2 or 3 the Spanish side is up, on 4, 5 or 6 the Dutch side. Each player gets three leaders to control their armies and 15 units of infantry. The Spanish get an extra two units of cavalry and the Dutch two units of naval troops (watergeuzen)
Each round both players roll a die. Their separate scores are the number of action points they have for that round. The combined number of both dies is used to decide on a random effect to be carried out before the round is started. 
Victory points can only be scored as the result of a specific random effect. For each province (there are 16 provinces with 1 to 8 cities) where one players controls all cities that player scores a victory point for each city in the province. 
The player with the highest roll starts the round, in case of a tie the Spanish player. Units are moved over the board by leaders, they cannot move alone. The naval units can move independently but only from one coastal city to another. Movement costs actions. A player can conquer cities by spending action points storming, starving or tricking them. A random event can cause the city to change its alliance at the start of a new round as well.
Battles between armies are  a special affair: both sides take only one turn rolling dies, one die for a unit of infantry, three for cavalry and three for each point their best leaders ability is higher than the other players best leaders. First the defending player rolls the dies, scoring a hit for each 6 rolled. Then, after taking her losses, the attacker does the same, the defender taking her losses. The winner of the battle is the player who rolled the most sixes or, when both rolled the same number, the defender. The defeated player loses the entire army, both units and leaders!
After the last round there is a final victory point calculation. In this calculation a point is awarded for each city the player controls, regardless of province control.

Name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – Spawn of Madness Asylum Pack
Description:
In Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game - Spawn of Madness, chaos explodes through a series of powerful events and support cards. "The Sleeper Awakens!" for the Cthulhu faction will clear the board of characters while Yog-Sothoth's "Revelation of the Spheres" will steal characters before opponents have a chance to play them. Madness, Disasters, Monsters, and Servitors lurk in Spawn of Madness!

Spawn of Madness first appeared as an Asylum pack when that game was being published in a CCG format. In 2011, Fantasy Flight Games revised Spawn of Madness to fit its Living Card Game format, with three copies each of twenty different cards. The card text has been updated to reflect the most recent FAQ and errata.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Call of Cthulhu – The Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Bonus Adventures – Servants of the Thunder Shaman
Description:
Three scenarios for Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game, combining the Castle Ravenloft and Wrath of Ashardalon components. Rules for playing the scenarios as a campaign are included.

Adventure 1: The Lost Souls: During a recent orc raid, several villagers were abducted.
Adventure 2: The Trap: An evil hag has allied with the Orc King!
Adventure 3: The Shaman and the Servant: Defeat the orc shaman before his flesh golem attacks the village!
Families: Series: Dungeons & Dragons Adventure System Board Games

Name: BARFIGHT!
Description:
Barfight! is a fast playing fifteen minute filler card game.

Players take the part of patrons in a typical Fantasy Tavern where the next barfight is just a spilled pint away...

Players draw cards from the Deck which include classic weapons such as Punches, Kicks, Bottles, Chairs, Drinks Trays etc or Dodges, Dodge Behind Victim (lets you pull someone else in the way!) or even Ricochets when an attack bounces off the wall and could go anywhere!

The aim of BARFIGHT! is to be the player who has suffered the least damage when all the cards have been played.

Did you spill my pint...?!

Name: Commander-In-Chief
Description:
Commander-In-Chief is a fun fast-playing abstract strategy war game published by X Plus Products in which a player's Air, Land and Sea military vehicles work as a unified Armed Forces assault team to "capture" their opponent's Commander. The board consists of a traditional 8 square x 8 square checkerboard grid divided into two Land areas separated by a Sea area. Vehicles are restricted to movement within their assigned battlefields: Through the Air, On Land and/or In the Sea.

Pieces transverse the board in a Chess-like manner.  Play evolves, turn by turn, with each player analyzing the current battlefield situation, adjusting their game plan accordingly and executing commands (movements of the playing pieces) in a collective effort to achieve the game's objective. Certain Air pieces (Bombers and Helicopters) can Go Over pieces; likewise certain Sea pieces (Submarines) can Go Under pieces. Additionally, certain pieces (Bombers and Tanks) can Block. The complete Original Release Basic Training Game Rules include "Object of the Game" options, "Team Game Play" options and "Advanced Game Play" options. "Future" options will include new movements, expansion pieces, additional damage control options, new attack features, mini wars and expanded terrains as variants to the Original Release Game Rules.

While this abstract strategy war game does not include random chance, it does allow for piece enhancements both during game play and during board set up which increases come from behind opportunities and can be used to level the playing field between players of various skill levels. The game can be played one-on-one or as a social game with teams. The military theme, the terrain feature of Air, Land and Sea areas of the board and the movements of the pieces themselves relative to the military vehicles they represent give the game a real world appeal.

The two Armed Forces consist of the following fifteen pieces per side: one Commander, two stealth Fighters, two army Tanks, one stealth Bomber, two submersible Submarine warships, two Helicopters, four amphibious assault vehicles (Amphibians) and one surface combatant Destroyer warship. This military themed board game, representing two Armed Forces, "Supports Our Troops" as the game of the "Y" by donating $1 to the Armed Services YMCA for every game sold.

Commander-In-Chief is a 3-In-1 board game that includes Chess & Checkers; these Classics are played on the dark and light colored side of the double sided game board. Additional game play options include: Tic-Tac-Toe and The Triangle Puzzle Game. Lastly, the 30 pieces that come with the game are miniatures, 30 Military Toys, designed for play with or without this board game and the 30 bases that the miniatures mount on, when inverted, become 30 Stackable Spinning Tops designed for multiple family fun games.

Name: Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara
Description:
In Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara, you are one of the feudal lords taking part in the grand battle of Moegahara, where the lands are to be divided. Joining forces with either East or West, you must use your finances and deploy your forces wisely, while keeping a keen eye on your enemy's moves.

Kunitori! Kessen: The Battle of Moegahara is set in the same world as the other Kunitori! titles, but is a standalone game for two, four or six players that cannot be used as an expansion for those games. Players form two teams; each player starts with a deck of eight cards and gradually buys more cards from the card pool to add to his army. Eventually the armies are deployed to the front line, where the two teams compete for a majority of the land cards displayed there.

Name: Gensokyo Project Practical Joke
Description:
A bluffing game for 3–10 players (6 or more preferred).

The game consists of a deck of of cards, representing ten different practical jokes. The cards are all dealt to the players who then play out these practical jokes on each other, face down, claiming aloud it's of a specific kind. The player who is hit can either call it (a lie or the truth) or send the practical joke on to another player. If a player calls it and is wrong, he gains the practical joke card(s) as penalty points (not added to his hand) and also gains a power card that he can use for his benefit later in the game.

The game ends when one player runs out of cards, at which point all cards in hand are added as penalty points. The player with the least penalty point wins.

The art in this game is all based on characters from the Project Shrine Maiden, a series of home-made shooting games for Windows.
Families: Video Game Theme: Project Shrine Maiden

Name: Gensokyo ritual
Description:
A set-collecting card game with auctioned turn order, based on characters and situations from Project Shrine Maiden, a series of amateur shooting games for Windows.

Gensokyo ritual comes in independent two-deck packages, which all can be played separately with 2–4 players or together with more players.

Players are dealt a number of "liquor" cards. Each turn, a number of character cards and event cards are drawn and revealed, and the turn order is auctioned out using these liquor cards. Players then gain one character card of their choice from the ones displayed and may also try to complete any of the face up event cards. The Event are the cards that are worth victory points, and in order to gain them, the player must discard the number of character cards mentioned on the event card.

As there never is any hand renewal of the liquor cards, they must be use wisely.
Families: Video Game Theme: Project Shrine Maiden

Name: Win the Spell Card Battle
Description:
User summary:

A light-weight card game, a version of UNO, based on characters  from Project Shrine Maiden, a series of amateur shooting games for Windows.

Of a deck consisting of coloured cards numbered 0–9 and some cards with special effects, players are dealt 7 cards each. A card from the deck is drawn and placed on the table, and the starting player may then only play a card from his hand that matches number or colour. If he can't, he must draw a card from the deck. Play goes on until someone managed to get rid of all his cards and thus wins.

Of the cards with special effects, there are cards that change the turn order, cards that jump the next player's turn, cards that forces the next player to draw cards, wild cards that change colour, counter cards that counter whatever the latest effect was, and so on.

About every single card has a unique illustration.
Families: Video Game Theme: Project Shrine Maiden

Name: Warhammer: Storm of Magic
Description:
[Publisher website]
Storm of Magic is an expansion for Warhammer, the Game of Fantasy Battles. Launched in July 2011, Storm of Magic describes what happens when great eldritch maelstroms roil across the lands. Magic becomes far more powerful and there is a whole range of Cataclysm spells to cast, unleashing untold devastation on the enemy. Arcane Fulcrums burst from the ground, not only acting as loci for the swirling energies that pervade a battle fought amidst the Storm of Magic, but changing the way a Warhammer tabletop looks and interacts with your armies.

Name: Große Sprünge: kleine Sprünge
Description:
Goal: Be third on target to win

1. Each player chooses 2 (plastic) frogs (same colour)
2. Try to reach as quick as possible (rolling the dice by turns) the marked (dead) zone  
3. Try to optimize (by dice) your position(s) for the final leap 
4. Cross the target on third position

Name: La gara motociclistica
Description:
It reproduces the development of a race of motorbike of the duration of 4 turns.
Every player chooses a motorbike and takes the relative card with tachometer.
Using of the cards movement he moves himself to us along the distance. Who wins arrives for first to the goal.
Contained: map he represents a track, cards, 4 motorbike in plastic, 4 cards with tachometer and handbook.

Name: Panzer Grenadier: Carpathian Brigade
Description:
A supplemental scenario book for the Panzer Grenadier game series by Avalanche Press. The supplement address real, abortive and hypothetical battles of Polish exiles in North Africa. There are 11 scenarios total.

The scenario geography is primarily around Tobruch but there are scenarios of the East Libyan desert and El Alamein. In addition to the famous title unit, the Carpathian Lancers, 1st Polish Artillery Regiment, and 2nd Warsaw Armored Brigade also get turns in the spotlight.

Stated requirements for play are Desert Rats, Cassino ’44, and White Eagles. Players knowledgeable with the series will be able to find adequate substitutions for units, if they don't have all of the supporting games. Desert Rats however is a firm requirement, as it provides the maps.

Name: Nefertiti: La Barque Solaire
Description:
Nefertiti - La Barque Solaire is included in Plato magazine No. 31.

La Barque Solaire is the French name for the Khufu ship.

This is an intact full-size vessel from Ancient Egypt that was sealed into a pit in the Giza pyramid complex at the foot of the Great Pyramid of Giza around 2500 BC. The ship was almost certainly built for Khufu (King Cheops), the second pharaoh of the Fourth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom of Egypt.

Name: S'getti Scatter
Description: The game includes a large white plastic bowl and lots of colorful plastic pieces of spaghetti that fit around the top rim of the bowl. Three S'getti meatballs are placed on the spaghetti. Children remove the spaghetti pieces one by one without letting the meatballs fall through to the bottom when the bowl upsets and spills the spaghetti and meatballs on the table. The player who causes the meatball to fall in the pot is the loser.

Name: Do-Dé
Description:
Goal: Be the first to get rid of all taken 'Dominoes'-cards

Game consists of 2 black/red dice and 78 cards, which show two different sides - halfway through
printed in red and black with symbols from 1 to 6, infrequently a joker.

1. Each player draws 6 cards
2. Roll the dice: If someone owns a card with matching symbols he/she may start putting this side up in the middle of the table. If no one has a matching card all the players must draw an additional one and roll the dice again.
3. Now proceed adding your cards by turn according 'Dominoes', but you must roll the dice first or you choose the dice result of your predecessor: Only the those numbers can be placed with matching numbers to cards on the table AND on the dice; a Joker may be placed at any combination. During your turn you may add further cards, which have to match with cards on the table only.
4. If you have finished your turn draw a new card from the pile
5. Check the dice results of the other players carefully; if you possess a  matching card the turn is yours, as long as you are quick enough
6. Placing your last card on the table - you win

Name: Symmetrion
Description:
Goal: Be the first who achieves a predefined pattern with your plugs

1. Each player gets 5 coloured plugs
2. Players choose a (predefined) pattern (on a 6 x 6 matrix)
3. Put all your plugs by turns into the holes
4. Move your plugs - you may not jump over - thus you can block your opponent
5. Create the required pattern and win

Name: Dungeon of Dread
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

Fantastic treasure lies deep within the Dungeon of Dread, but to find it you must survive a deadly gauntlet. Heroes band together to form adventuring parties and face off against monsters and villains in the dungeon—but the adventure doesn't end there!

Dungeon of Dread is an exciting, cooperative board game experience in which heroes unite in battle to achieve a common goal and defeat the enemies standing in their way. If they succeed, glory and fortune will be theirs for the taking. If they fail, all could be lost!

This cooperative board game experience is designed for 2-5 players, ages 10 and up. One player is the Dungeon Master who runs the villains and monsters; the remaining players are the heroes. The game includes four adventures, each one featuring a unique villain.

Update, August 11, 2011

Apparently Dungeon of Dread was not as "exciting" as Wizards of the Coast hoped for, as the company announced at Gen Con 2011 that the title was no longer scheduled for release.

Name: Metapontum Peace Chess
Description:
Metapontum is a cooperative abstract strategy game created and promoted by Dutch designer Hans Theo Frenkel and the foundation he created, for the purpose of promoting world peace. It is played on an 8x8 hexagonal board with 16 pieces on each side, that have movement very similar to those in Chess, and are abstract as in Chess. The goal of Metapontum is for both sides to exchange their pieces from their chosen opening setup to their chosen end setup in a minimum amount of moves. On every turn, a player can either move one of his pieces or exchange one of his pieces with one of his opponent's, as long as his piece has line of sight to the other.

Frenkel's web site sells various game boards made out of either cardboard, wood or stone. Frenkel claims that all games are produced under fair trade practices.

Name: Street FM
Description:
User summary:
A basic set of skirmish-level miniatures rules for urban combat between street gangs, law enforcement, special forces, etc. Game scale is 1:1 with each figure representing individual fighters, vehicles, etc. Each turn equals 5 seconds of "real" time and the ground scale is 1.5 centimeters equals 1 meter.
